awd_titl_txt: CDI-Type I:   Accelerating Simulations Using CPU+FPGA Heterogeneous Processing
awd_abstract_narration: The computational modeling of biological and physiological processes is becoming a growing component of any comprehensive research effort aimed at understanding complex systems. A significant limitation to such studies is the computational efficiency used to assess complex data sets that often span multiple time scales. An example of this is the heart which is one of the most important organs in the body, and for which computational modeling is becoming increasingly important to understanding its function. In addition to the large number of cells in the heart, computational modeling and simulation of cardiac function becomes extremely complex when considering both the feedback inherent in many cardiac processes (requiring a fine timescale) and the long-term effects of various stimuli (requiring long simulations). Multi-timescale simulations are therefore required. This project will utilize cardiac function as a model system to develop new and faster computational tools. New processing capabilities will be developed for automatically partitioning intra- and inter-time-step computation among heterogeneous processing units that are now becoming commonplace in commodity computer systems. In particular, computation will be partitioned and mapped to graphics processing units (GPUs) and field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) in addition to general-purpose central processing units (CPUs), with each processing unit targeting different types of parallelism and computational bottlenecks. These capabilities will dramatically accelerate multi-timescale simulation and other computationally complex algorithms, providing an improved understanding of cardiac function and other complex systems. The project will produce an open-source resource for partitioning computation to heterogeneous computing units that will be broadly useful across a range of disciplines. The research will provide interdisciplinary training for graduate students in systems biology and computer science. In addition to carrying out much of the research on this project, these students will also perform outreach aimed to encourage younger students to pursue careers in science and engineering.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Our models of the two major biochemical pathways coupling electrical and calcium signals to altered gene expression (calcineurin/NFAT and CaMKII/HDAC pathways) are key contributions to cardiac research, and our Netflux software makes such models accessible to other researchers.

Our work on automata processing shows that the automata paradigm on spatial architectures (Automata Processor and FPGA) can provide profound speedups across a range of applications that had not previously been considered for an automata approach. These application areas include pattern mining, bioinformatics, and simulation methods. The automata research led us to develop a set of tools for automata processing research, and a programming and runtime infrastructure for “write-once, run-anywhere”. This allows a programmer to write a single version of their automata or pattern-matching task and then automatically have it run efficiently on the best available accelerator, or be partitioned across heterogeneous computing resources.  This allows pattern-oriented and Markov-style applications such as various bioinformatics tasks to seamlessly leverage CPU, FPGA, AP, and other accelerators as appropriate.

We also developed key improvements in CPU power management and cache management.

Broader impacts, in addition to the dissemination of these findings, are primarily in research tools, all software: the Netflux cardiac modeling tool; the Lumos heterogeneous processor architecture design-space exploration tool; the ANMLZoo benchmark suite for research in automata processing; the RAPID programming language for pattern-matching tasks; the iNFAnt2 GPU automata processing tool; and VASim, which is both a simulator for researching novel automata processing architectures, as well as a software runtime for “production use” to give programmers a “write-once, run-anywhere” programming and runtime environment for pattern-matching and other automata-based algorithms.  All these software tools are released open-source on the Web. Through workshops and internships, URM high school and undergraduate students were introduced to computational modeling of biological networks.  In addition, throughout the various phases of the project, both undergraduate and graduate research assistants learned state-of-the-art research techniques.
